article:
How is Europe faring in the pandemic? In the mountains of Switzerland lives a farmer in a village where there hasn't yet been a single case of the disease.
Lesen Sie diesen Text auf Deutsch
How are our European neighbors doing in the pandemic? What is life like
these days in France, Ireland, Bulgaria and elsewhere? In the series "We
Neighbors", Europeans will be talking about their everyday lives: the taxi
driver in Dublin, the mother in Paris working from home, the theater family in
Bulgaria. They all are also taking part in Europe Talks, a discussion event for
which ZEIT ONLINE, together with media partners from 15 countries, is
registering participants. On Dec. 13, thousands of people from across Europe
will meet another European to discuss and debate the corona crisis.
"In
our village in the middle of the Swiss mountains, we have realized something
quite amazing: Apparently we have been unwittingly adhering to social distancing
rules here since long before the pandemic. Our village is small, and we all
live close together. We run into each other during the day at the fence or on
the street – there's not much of a need to have a coffee together and get too
close. We rarely shake hands, pretty much never, really. We keep our distance
quite naturally. It is something we did even before there were official corona
rules. We didn't have to change anything about our behavior or our daily lives
in the village.
It's
a strange situation. There are only 30 people living in our village of
Tersnaus, in the canton of Graubünden. So far, we haven't had even a single
coronavirus infection here. I hear on the radio and see on television what is
happening out there in the world. It bothers me and I think about it a lot. At
the same time, though, the cows are still standing outside, they need to eat so
we keep feeding them, or we maybe have to put up a new fence. It keeps me grounded.
I'm
rather surprised by how relaxed I am at the moment, though I take the situation
seriously, of course. During the spring, we had a few hundred cases a day in
Switzerland at the peak. Now, it's thousands, but perhaps that is because we
are doing more testing. There are huge ads in the paper: Get tested! Even if
you just have a minor sore throat. Maybe I'm so relaxed because I am able to
keep away from it all due to where I live. In my daily life, corona is
literally far away.
My
husband and I run an organic farm and we don't take any milk from our cows,
instead leaving it to them so they can raise their calves. We are in the
business of selling meat – mixed packages that include everything from the nose
to the tail. You can't just order a filet or an entrecôte from us. We want the
animal to be valued in its entirety. During the pandemic, demand for our meat
has risen, which I am of course pleased about.
Ten
years ago, we set up two holiday apartments in the old village schoolhouse next
door. We have always enjoyed our interactions with our guests. There's us with
our farm in a mountain village and they come in from completely different lives
in the big city: Zürich, Bern or even Berlin.
We
have kept our guesthouse open throughout the pandemic, and it has been
extremely well-received. We had an older couple from Basel booked for a week in
April, for example. When the discussion began in March of a possible lockdown
or even a strict stay-at-home order, I told them that they could stay longer if
they wanted or even come earlier. They arrived that same evening.
They
said that they got a lot of disapproving looks in the train. It was quite a
stigma for older people: They're going out despite the danger they face?! But
here, they were able to move around freely. That is the thing that most guests
appreciate the most: that they are completely unbothered. The couple ended up
staying 10 weeks. We started calling them "our corona refugees" as a
joke. We were happy to have them.
People
come to us for peace and quiet – and to escape the pandemic. Those who want to
are welcome to help out around the farm. Some people like feeding the animals
or grooming them. Others don't mind splitting wood for hours at a time. There
are even some who voluntarily shovel manure. It's something that I really
value, sharing this feeling that a life in the mountains is so incredibly
grounding.
At
the same time, I've often wondered: Is it really a good idea to host people in
the guesthouse? What would the village say if I welcomed strangers who might be
carrying the virus? But I think the risk is low. In the best case, our guests
arrive by car and live in apartments that are self-contained. They are careful,
and it's easy to maintain social distancing in the village.
We
have all learned how to live with the virus. In the spring, we had quite a
strict lockdown for six weeks. Now, the schools are open, as are the shops. And
it's working! People used the summer to get ready: Shops and restaurants are
well-prepared. My husband and I could even go to the movies or to classical
concerts – but with masks, a limited number of spectators and a hygiene and health
safety plan.
I
think the state has done a good job. In the first lockdown, the Federal Council
– our government – took the decisions. Now, though, the government is giving a
lot of power back to the cantons. I think that is the correct move. It allows
the cantons to independently react to the situation locally. In the canton of
Bern, there is a lockdown, but here in Graubünden, we don't have one at the
moment. Our European neighbors think we are being too lackadaisical, but for
me, it’s the right approach. Measured.
Rural
depopulation has long been an issue in Switzerland. Young people are leaving
and moving to the cities. But in recent years, it has looked as though the
trend is reversing, and the pandemic has accelerated that. People are returning
to the countryside. I hope that will continue once the pandemic has passed.
Life in the country and in the mountains – it's a good life."
